UX form design

The UX behind designing better forms and best practice

Forms allow users to communicate with businesses and to collect valuable information. Many form standards are making their way into AR, VR, MR and Marketing Automation Platforms like Hubspot and Marketo. UX form design should be thoughtful and thorough. Here are a couple of notes and observations.

Multi-step forms out-perform single-step forms

Splitting your forms into two or three steps will almost always increase form completion. We’ve tested this across all kinds of lead generation forms, from webinar registration forms to B2B enquiry forms, and consistently we’ve found multi-step forms out-perform generic single-step forms.

Reference: https://www.ventureharbour.com/form-design-best-practices/

Single column layouts are superior to multiple columns

A short study conducted by ConversionXL Institute compared completion time on a single column form vs. a multicolumn form. Survey participants completed the linear, single-column form (n = 356) an average of 15.4 seconds faster than the multi-column form (n = 346). This was significantly faster at a 95% confidence level.

Reference: https://conversionxl.com/research-study/form-field-usability/

Inline form validation

Web forms aren’t great for conversions and offer a monologue experience, where the user is asked a host of questions before waiting for a response.

Real-time inline validation helps users to complete web forms faster, with less effort and fewer errors. Real-time feedback is provided, helping to suggest valid answers, and providing updates to meet any necessary limits.

Adding inline form validation in one study led to an 22% increase in success rates, plus:

  • 22% decrease in errors made
  • 42% decrease in completion times
  • 47% decrease in the number of eye fixations
  • 31% increase in satisfaction rating

Reference: https://alistapart.com/article/inline-validation-in-web-forms

Top aligning labels is best

By placing a label above an input field, users aren’t forced to look separately at the label and the input field. In comparison, placing labels to the left of input fields imposes a heavy cognitive workload on the user. Placing labels above input fields is preferable, but if you choose to place them to the left of input fields, at least make them right aligned.

“Bold labels resulted in an almost sixty-percent increase in saccade time to move from the label to the input field.”

Reference: https://www.uxmatters.com/mt/archives/2006/07/label-placement-in-forms.php

Communicate form errors

It’s crucial to clearly communicate form errors to increase conversions. Simply highlighting the field in red and displaying the error at the top of the form will assist the user.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf

Radio buttons perform better than dropdowns

Based on recent survey results, participants complete radio button forms an average of (n = 354) 2.5 seconds faster than forms with select menu buttons or dropdowns, with a 95% increase in confidence.

Reference: https://conversionxl.com/research-study/form-field-usability-buttons/

Use input length as an affordance

Input fields need to be consistent in width and provide some hints on what the content should be.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf

Group relevant content together

Grouping relevant content together will assist users to understand related content, without the distraction of too many visual elements.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf

Offer field focus/zoom on mobile

We can improve user experience by offering field focus/zoom, making it easier for the user to edit text.

Reference: https://jenson.org/small/

Notify users ahead of time if information will take time to obtain

Forms work best when the information required is readily available. Difficult information should be collected ahead of time to speed up completion.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf

Disable the submit button after a user completes a form

Disable the submit button after completion to prevent multiple submissions.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf

Keep form fields to a minimal

Imagescape reported an increase in conversion by 120% by reducing the fields in their forms from 11 to 4.

Reference: https://unbounce.com/conversion-rate-optimization/how-to-optimize-contact-forms/

Use smart defaults to help speed up form completion

Smart defaults set a clear path to guide users through a form and speed up completion times.

Use active voice in CTA copy to increase CTR by 90%

An Unbounce.com PPC campaign increased CTR by 90% by simply changing one word in their copy, replacing the possessive determiner “You” with “My” to become ‘Start my free 30-day trial’.

Reference: https://unbounce.com/conversion-rate-optimization/design-call-to-action-buttons/

Use different shapes and colours on a primary CTA

Changing the colour and shape of a call-to-action can increase the click through rate (CTR) by 35.81%.

Reference: https://unbounce.com/conversion-rate-optimization/design-call-to-action-buttons/

Phone number fields can decrease conversion by 39%

ClickTale designed a solution which only displays the phone number field as optional if the user selects it. This nearly doubled the conversation rate (43% to 80%) and decreased the drop-out rate from 39% to only 4%.

Reference: http://www.smallfarmdesign.com/blog/2010/06/07/how-form-design-affects-customers/

Submit isn’t good for CTA copy

Carefully select your CTA copy for submitting forms, be contextual.

Reference: https://unbounce.com/conversion-rate-optimization/how-to-optimize-contact-forms/

CATPCHAs reduce conversion rates

A study by Stanford University found that Captchas will cost you a drop in subscribers / leads of up to 30%. When Animoto removed captchas from their sign-up form, they received 33.3% more signups. A better alternative would be to use an automated spam detection service like Akismet, or create a ‘honeypot’ using hidden fields.

Reference: https://www.ventureharbour.com/form-design-best-practices/

Don’t break the “single line of sight”

Secondary actions (like cancel) require clear visual distinction. Don’t break the “single line of sight.” All primary actions should be aligned with the form inputs – there needs to be a clear path to completion. Any secondary actions need to be visually distinct, and not be within the line of sight of completion.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf

Minimise tips and help required. It interrupts the user

Minimise help and tips when users are trying to complete a form. If it’s absolutely necessary, it needs to be done in a way which will not interrupt the flow of the form. Consider a dynamic help system.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf

Markup: set the tab order using tabindex to ensure proper tabbing

Tabbing is useful from a usability perspective on web and mobile. A tabindex attribute will help users complete the form in a timely manner.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf

Markup: use label, and fieldset where possible, not just input

A label tag is clickable/tappable and associates the input with a label for screen readers. Fieldsets are useful to group content together for accessibility.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf

After successful completion of the form: provide feedback in the context of the form

Celebrate the form completion! And let users know (in context of the form) what has happened now that they’ve submitted.

Reference: https://static.lukew.com/webforms_lukew.pdf
